node.title: Trustee
node.Description: Role Trustees, as voting members of the Board, are responsible for the overall governance and strategic direction of the Centre, developing the Centre's aims, objectives and goals in accordance with its governing documents, legal and regulatory guidelines and monitoring its performance. Main responsibilities of a Trustee To determine the overall direction and development of the Centre through good governance and clear strategic planning. To ensure the Centre and its representatives function within the legal and regulatory framework governing the activities of the Centre, in line with the Centre's governing documents, continually striving for best practice in governance. To maintain and develop the Centre's standing in the communities it serves and reputation and influence, continually striving for best practice in governance.   Main duties of a Trustee To contribute actively to the Board's role in giving clear strategic direction to the Centre, setting overall policy objectives, defining goals, setting targets and evaluating performance against agreed objectives. To ensure that the Centre complies with its governing documents, and also charity law, company law, and any other relevant legislation or regulations. To ensure that appropriate arrangements (including a clear governance and management structure) are in place for the Centre to deliver its objects. This SNC Trustee Role Description Page 2 of 3 includes appointing, supporting, monitoring and reviewing the effectiveness of the Centre's Chief Executive. Maintain sound financial management of the charity's resources, ensuring expenditure is in line with the Centre's objects, and investment activities meet accepted standards and policies. To ensure that the property of the Centre is properly protected, managed and safeguarded. To safeguard the good name and values of the Centre. To maintain confidentiality, disclose any conflicts of interest and abide by the Centre's Trustees Code of Conduct. In addition to the above main statutory duties, each Trustee should use any skills, knowledge or experience he/she may have to help the Board of Trustees reach sound decisions. This may involve leading on certain key issues, providing advice and guidance on matters which the Trustee has special expertise, etc.

node.title: School Governor (Harrow)
node.Description: Governing bodies are responsible for the strategic management of a school and will make decisions about a wide range of issues The core responsibilities involved are: •Ensuring accountability •Acting as a ‘critical friend’ to the Head Teacher •Monitoring and evaluating the school’s progress •Budgetary allocation and control •Shaping plans for school improvement and overseeing their implementation •Setting the school’s aims and values •Appointing senior members of staff including the Head Teacher The governing body is usually split in to a small number of committees, each responsible for one area such as finance or pupil achievement. These committees will meet separately from the main governing body to discuss relevant issues in more detail. Discussion is then fed back at a full governing body meeting. A school governing body is made up of representatives from the school, the parents, the local authority and the local community.

node.title: Bookkeeper
node.Description: As Volunteer Bookkeeper you will be required to: Use QuickBooks to maintain all finances for the organisation. Work closely with an Accountant working on a freelance basis to follow process and ensure the smooth running of the organisation. Work compliantly in adherence to audit guidelines and government protocol in order to ensure as a charity they are operating in the correct way. Keep records of donation and claiming Gift Aid, daily banking and petty cash, invoices and expenses, payment of accounts and bills amongst other financial responsibilities. Producing management reports. Excellent communication skills with the ability to multi task. Prepare end of year accounts for audit. A flexible approach to working and a team player spirit to often think outside of the job description to help the rest of the team.

node.title: Trustee
node.Description: Experienced Trustees required for the Centre. Sudbury Neighbourhood Centre is a community centre, located in the London Borough of Brent that provides a range of activities and services (including a day care service) to the people in the surrounding communities. We are governed by a Board of Trustees and are seeking to appoint new people to the Board, who will become Trustees, and make a contribution to the overall direction of the organisation.  We are seeking individuals with a passion for our work, who have skills and experience they can bring to the overall future direction of the charity.  In particular, we’d like to hear from you if you have knowledge or skills in:   Management in the voluntary or public sectors Marketing Finance and Fundraising Adult social care sector   Our Board of Trustees usually meets every other month.  As volunteers our Trustees receive no payment for their contribution to the Centre. We welcome people from the widest possible diversity of background, culture and experience to help ensure that the Board is representative of the communities we serve.

node.title: Community Champion
node.Description: Burnt Oak is an area of Barnet in North London where a significant number of people are not engaged with technology. They make struggle to produce a CV using word-processing or fill-in an online application for a job or a benefit. They may never have bought anything on-line despite the fact that the savings made could be really useful for them. In other areas there are Coffee 'n Computers projects where people can drop in to get the help they need (and a quick refreshment). Each project needs a leader and a small team of volunteers to provide the help that it needed. Here in Burnt Oak we need to find that volunteer for the leadership role. We don't have a detailed list of what you WILL do. However it is easy to say what you WON'T do. You are not here to fix people's broken technology but to help them make best use of whatever is in their hand, be it PC, SMART phone or something else. A simple example might be that a person acquires some new equipment (e.g. laptop) and just needs someone to shop them how to use it.

node.title: Literacy Trainer (The Princess Alexandra Home)
node.Description: Duties will include: • Administering pre-training assessment • Agreeing learning objectives with manager and staff member in advance of training • Working one-to-one or small group with identified staff on their literacy – verbal and written • Working one-to-one or small group to enable staff to complete relevant documentation • Attending volunteer meetings to report back to the group and offering any learning or recommendations for the project

node.title: Into Work Volunteer
node.Description: An opportunity for anyone with skills, experience and a successful track record in HR, Recruitment or a similar role to help others who are currently unwaged/unemployed. Love Burnt Oak operates IntoWork on a Tuesday morning, twice a month, at its resource centre on Watling Avenue and short walk from the Underground Station. As a volunteer you will be helping people to: make better use of the Internet in job search using our suite of PCs; share your experiences of effective job search including CV writing and preparing for interviews and share whatever knowledge you have which will enable another person to move from being a jobseeker to an employee. IntoWork operates on the 1st/3rd Tuesday of each month but you don't have to make it to every session. Love Burnt Oak started in 2012 and is a community organisation in the Burnt Oak area of North London Love Burnt Oak is committed to improving the life chances of local residents; many of whom face disadvantages associated with poverty, unemployment, health issues, disability and other personal circumstances. Burnt Oak is a multi-cultural area with many languages including: English, Romanian, Polish, Guajarati, Farsi and Nepalese. Love Burnt Oak welcomes people of all faiths (including Christian, Muslim, Hindu, Buddhist) and none. As Burnt Oak is a multicultural area, volunteers who speak other community languages are most welcome. Love Burnt Oak contributes to essential volunteer expenses. We do not provide initial training in job search skills but will provide support, particularly during the induction period, to all volunteers.

node.title: Quality Assurance Volunteer
node.Description: The Quality Assurance group aims to help Jami reflect on its activities and find the best ways of working, in order to become more effective and efficient. Jami is a charity which supports the recovery of Jewish people with a history of mental illness. The group aims to help Jami reflect on its activities and find the best ways of working, in order to become more effective and efficient. Jami is a charity which supports the recovery of Jewish people with a history of mental illness. The group meet approximately every two months. The group members are expected to attend the meetings and follow up on identified tasks in between meetings. The time commitment is variable but would not amount to more than two days per month.

node.title: Social Researcher
node.Description: The Social Research volunteer will be responsible for supporting the staff team with designing and implementing a large-scale research project to measure the outcomes, impact and social return on investment of the services provided by Chalkhill Community Centre. This will involve: surveys, telephone questionnaires and focus groups; analysis of data and writing up the research paper of findings. The volunteer will be required to help to design and carry out surveys, questionnaires and focus groups using appropriate research methodology. They will collate and analyse research data and help to prepare a report of findings.

node.title: Fundraising Volunteer
node.Description: The volunteer will be required to work with the fundraising consultant research trusts and corporate grant making foundations appropriate to the charity's aims and objectives. They will also need to prepare funding applications and support help to develop the fundraising strategy. The volunteer will work with all forms of media, producing supporting materials such as case studies.
